abstract.p: Pres Clinton's $1.77 trillion fiscal 2000 budget seeks record $33.9 billion for environmental programs, increase of 5 percent over 1999 (S)

block.p: The Administration is seeking a record $33.9 billion for environmental programs next year, an increase of 5 percent over this year's spending.

Perhaps the hardest part of the budget to sell in Congress will be the $4 billion for fighting the risk of global warming, mainly by spurring research and investments in energy efficiency. But even industry lobbyists who have opposed a proposed international treaty to reduce emissions of heat-trapping gases welcomed some of the proposals, saying they would help companies take voluntary steps.
The Administration is seeking a record $33.9 billion for environmental programs next year, an increase of 5 percent over this year's spending.

Perhaps the hardest part of the budget to sell in Congress will be the $4 billion for fighting the risk of global warming, mainly by spurring research and investments in energy efficiency. But even industry lobbyists who have opposed a proposed international treaty to reduce emissions of heat-trapping gases welcomed some of the proposals, saying they would help companies take voluntary steps.

Along with hefty increases in Federal energy research, the budget seeks $3.6 billion in tax breaks over the next five years for renewable energy investments and for purchases of energy-efficient homes, cars and appliances. Congress has turned down similar ideas before.

Another major initiative calls for spending $1 billion next year to buy land for conservation, a record amount. Like several other environmental proposals, this one had already been announced by the White House.

Other highlights include $312 million for restoring the Everglades, $2.3 billion for programs to clean up polluted waters, $1.5 billion for cleaning up Superfund toxic waste dumps, and $1.8 billion for transportation programs intended to ease traffic congestion to help cut air pollution.

The environmental proposals emphasize aid to states and cities, including matching grants for air pollution programs and $700 million in tax credits over five years to subsidize the issuance of $9.5 billion in conservation bonds. Of the Environmental Protection Agency's request for $7.2 billion next year, 40 percent would be funneled to state and local governments, officials said.
